title: The Parish of St. Stanislaus the Bishop and Martyr (Suszec, Poland)
text:
The Parish of St. Stanislaus the Bishop and Martyr in Suszec is a <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic</a> <a href="Parish%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">parish</a> in the <a href="Suszec">Suszec</a> <a href="deanery">deanery</a>.
History.
The <a href="parish">parish</a> was first mentioned in the 1326 register of the <a href="O%C5%9Bwi%C4%99cim">Oświęcim</a> <a href="deanery">deanery</a> of the <a href="Cracow">Cracow</a> <a href="diocese">diocese</a> as "Susechz" and again in 1327 as "Susecz." In the next <a href="Census">censuses</a> of feast days from 1346 to 1358 "Susecz", "Susecz", "Suczecz". Around 1350 the <a href="Pszczyna">Pszczyna</a> deanery was created and it was subordinate to the diocese of <a href="Krak%C3%B3w">Kraków</a> until 1821, when by virtue of the <a href="papal%20bull">papal bull</a> "De salute animarum" of 17 July it was attached to the diocese of <a href="Wroc%C5%82aw">Wrocław</a>.
In November 1598, a church inspection (the first after <a href="Council%20of%20Trent">the Council of Trent</a>) of the Pszczyna deanery was conducted by the <a href="archdeacon">archdeacon</a> of <a href="Krak%C3%B3w">Krakow</a>, Krzysztof Kazimirski, commissioned by <a href="bishop">bishop</a> Jerzy Radziwiłł. According to the report, the church in Villa Susiecz was in the hands of <a href="Lutheranism">Lutherans</a>.
In 1693 the main altar was consecrated to <a href="Stanislaus%20of%20Szczepan%C3%B3w">St. Stanislaus</a>, but since 1703 there have been paintings of the <a href="Apostles%20in%20the%20New%20Testament">Apostles</a> <a href="James%20the%20Great">James</a> and <a href="Philip%20the%20Apostle">Philip</a>. The right <a href="altar">altar</a> was then dedicated to the <a href="Mary%2C%20mother%20of%20Jesus">Mother of God</a>, and the left one to <a href="Saint%20Barbara">St. Barbara</a>. On the tower hung two <a href="bronze">bronze</a> <a href="Bell">bells</a>: St. Stanislaus and <a href="John%20of%20Nepomuk">St. John of Nepomuk</a>.
As a result of a fire on May 22, 1770 the entire church burned down. In its place, <a href="The%20Reverend">Rev</a>. Provincial Osiecki built a timber barracks out of his own pocket, which served as a religious building until about 1800.
As a result of moving the cemetery from the church square, a new church was built. The work was completed in 1804. The <a href="altar">altar</a> was dedicated to <a href="Stanislaus%20of%20Szczepan%C3%B3w">St. Stanislaus</a>, and in 1884 three side altars appeared: <a href="Mary%2C%20mother%20of%20Jesus">the Blessed Virgin Mary</a>, <a href="John%20of%20Nepomuk">St. John of Nepomuk</a>, and <a href="Anthony%20of%20Padua">St. Anthony of Padua</a>.
In 1895, the church burned down again. It was rebuilt by 1898 and consecrated in 1913.
Through battles during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the tower was destroyed. It was rebuilt in 1947. Over time, the church was repaired (ceiling, fence, sheet metal on the roof) and new rooms were added.
